0-28.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson are at the breakfast table discussing a walking stick left by their visitor, Dr. Mortimer. Holmes uses the stick to deduce information about Dr. Mortimer's profession and lifestyle.
0-28.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss the walking stick left by Dr. Mortimer, using it to deduce aspects of his life and profession. Holmes corrects Watson's deductions and guides him towards more accurate conclusions.
text_phrases: took the stick from my hands
carrying the cane to the window
looked over it again with a convex lens
returned to his favourite corner of the settee

29-56.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discuss Dr. Mortimer
29-56.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson discuss the details of Dr. Mortimer's career and character traits in their living room.
29-56.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss Dr. Mortimer's professional background and character traits, deducing aspects of his personality from his actions and career choices.
text_phrases: Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his settee
blew little wavering rings of smoke up to the ceiling

29-56.description: Dr. Mortimer arrives unexpectedly at Holmes and Watson's residence, surprising them with his appearance and mannerisms.
29-56.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer introduces himself and explains his reasons for visiting, showing great interest in Holmes's skills and expressing his admiration.
text_phrases: halted in the recess of the window
ran towards the stick with an exclamation of joy

57-78.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. James Mortimer engage in a conversation where Dr. Mortimer seeks Holmes' assistance with a mysterious problem related to a family manuscript. Holmes examines the manuscript and discusses its details.
57-78.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer seeks Holmes' help with a family manuscript related to the Baskerville family. Holmes examines the manuscript and identifies its age. Dr. Mortimer explains the manuscript's connection to Sir Charles Baskerville's recent death.
text_phrases: I have in my pocket a manuscript
Dr. Mortimer drew it from his breast-pocket
Holmes stretched out his hand for the manuscript and flattened it upon his knee
Dr. Mortimer turned the manuscript to the light and read

57-78.scene_title: The Legend of the Hound of the Baskervilles
57-78.description: Dr. Mortimer reads aloud a family legend from the manuscript concerning the origins of the Hound of the Baskervilles, detailing the story of Hugo Baskerville and his dark deeds that led to a curse on the Baskerville family.
57-78.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer reads a narrative from the manuscript about Hugo Baskerville's wicked actions and the subsequent curse involving a demonic hound.
text_phrases: Dr. Mortimer read in a high, cracking voice the following curious, old-world narrative
Of the origin of the Hound of the Baskervilles

79-91.description: A group of revellers, after realizing a grave deed was about to occur, hastily took to their horses under a clear moonlit sky to pursue a maiden and her pursuer, Hugo Baskerville, across the moorlands.
79-91.dialog_summary: The revellers inquire a shepherd if he had seen the hunt, who confirms seeing the maiden and Hugo Baskerville, followed by a terrifying hound.
text_phrases: Hugo Baskerville passed me upon his black mare
the black mare, dabbled with white froth, went past with trailing bridle

79-91.description: Three of the revellers, driven by either boldness or inebriation, discover the bodies of the maiden and Hugo Baskerville in a moonlit clearing, guarded by a monstrous hound.
79-91.dialog_summary: The three revellers are terrified by the sight of a monstrous hound standing over Hugo Baskerville's body.
text_phrases: two of those great stones, still to be seen there
a great, black beast, shaped like a hound
the thing tore the throat out of Hugo Baskerville

79-91.description: After reading a chilling narrative, Dr. Mortimer discusses the tale with Sherlock Holmes, who remains skeptical and dismissive of the supernatural elements.
79-91.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer reads a narrative and discusses it with Sherlock Holmes, who dismisses it as a fairy tale. Dr. Mortimer then introduces a more recent account from a newspaper.
text_phrases: pushed his spectacles up on his forehead
tossed the end of his cigarette into the fire
Dr. Mortimer drew a folded newspaper out of his pocket

92-100.scene_title: The Death of Sir Charles Baskerville
92-100.description: The scene describes the circumstances surrounding the death of Sir Charles Baskerville, his habits, and the discovery of his body.
92-100.dialog_summary: Barrymore recounts the events of Sir Charles's last night, including his usual walk and the discovery of his body.
text_phrases: walking down the famous yew alley
Sir Charles's footmarks were easily traced

92-100.scene_title: Discussion between Dr. Mortimer and Sherlock Holmes
92-100.description: Dr. Mortimer discusses the public facts of Sir Charles Baskerville's death with Sherlock Holmes and hints at withholding some private facts due to their sensitive nature.
92-100.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer presents the case of Sir Charles Baskerville's death to Sherlock Holmes, mentioning the public facts and his reluctance to share all details at the coroner's inquiry.

101-140.description: Dr. Mortimer describes Sir Charles's heightened anxiety due to the legend of the hound and his refusal to go out on the moor at night.
101-140.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer recounts Sir Charles's fear of the moor and the legend affecting his mental state.
text_phrases: Sir Charles's nervous system was strained
he would walk in his own grounds
nothing would induce him to go out upon the moor at night

101-140.description: Dr. Mortimer recalls visiting Sir Charles and witnessing his terrified reaction to something passing by, which he thought was a large black calf.
101-140.dialog_summary: Sir Charles is extremely agitated upon seeing something pass by, which leads Dr. Mortimer to investigate the spot.
text_phrases: eyes fix themselves over my shoulder
glimpse of something which I took to be a large black calf

101-140.scene_title: The Night of Sir Charles's Death
101-140.description: Dr. Mortimer details the events on the night of Sir Charles's death, including his examination of the scene and the body.
101-140.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer describes his observations of the scene where Sir Charles died, noting the footprints of a gigantic hound.
text_phrases: on the night of Sir Charles’s death
sent Perkins the groom on horseback
reach Baskerville Hall within an hour of the event
followed the footsteps down the yew alley
saw the spot at the moor-gate

141-185.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Mortimer discuss the mysterious circumstances surrounding Sir Charles's death near the moor-gate, focusing on the physical evidence and the supernatural elements reported.
141-185.dialog_summary: Holmes and Mortimer discuss the closed wicket-gate, the lack of marks by the gate, and the confusing evidence of Sir Charles's presence. Holmes expresses frustration at not being present to investigate the scene himself.
text_phrases: ash had twice dropped from his cigar
rain and defaced by the clogs of curious peasants

141-185.description: Holmes and Mortimer discuss the supernatural aspects of the case, with Mortimer revealing local sightings of a spectral creature and the terror it has caused. Mortimer seeks Holmes's advice regarding Sir Henry Baskerville's safety.
141-185.dialog_summary: Mortimer expresses his concerns about the supernatural creature seen on the moor and its implications for Sir Henry. Holmes remains skeptical of the supernatural explanations and discusses the practical aspects of protecting Sir Henry.

186-225.scene_title: Holmes and Mortimer Discuss Supernatural Theories
186-225.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Mortimer discuss the supernatural aspects of the case and Holmes advises Mortimer on how to proceed with Sir Henry Baskerville.
186-225.dialog_summary: Holmes dismisses the idea of a devil with only local powers and advises Mortimer to meet Sir Henry at Waterloo. Holmes requests Mortimer to bring Sir Henry to him the next day.
text_phrases: spaniel who is scratching at my front door
scribbled the appointment on his shirt-cuff

186-225.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the day's events and Holmes's deductions in a smoke-filled room.
186-225.dialog_summary: Holmes deduces Watson's activities and explains his own spiritual journey to Devonshire while physically staying in his armchair, surrounded by maps and tobacco.
text_phrases: room was so filled with smoke
light of the lamp upon the table was blurred
Holmes in his dressing-gown coiled up in an armchair
black clay pipe between his lips
rolls of paper lay around him
Holmes unrolled one section and held it over his knee

226-260.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson discuss the possibility of supernatural involvement in their case, considering the nature of the crime and the behavior of the suspect.
226-260.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss the possibility of supernatural forces and the logical steps to investigate the crime. Holmes suggests closing the window to concentrate better.
text_phrases: concentrated atmosphere helps a concentration of thought

226-260.description: Holmes and Watson analyze the details of the crime scene, particularly focusing on the behavior of the man who was running.
226-260.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss the peculiarities of the crime scene, including the change in footprints and the behavior of the suspect.

226-260.scene_title: Meeting with Sir Henry and Dr. Mortimer
226-260.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson meet with Dr. Mortimer and Sir Henry Baskerville to discuss the mysterious warning received by Sir Henry.
226-260.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson meet with Sir Henry and Dr. Mortimer. Sir Henry discusses a mysterious letter he received, warning him to stay away from the moor.
text_phrases: laid an envelope upon the table
opened and spread flat upon the table

261-290.description: Sherlock Holmes, Dr. Mortimer, and Sir Henry Baskerville discuss a mysterious document that Holmes deduces was cut from a newspaper. The scene is set in a room where they examine and discuss the implications of the document.
261-290.dialog_summary: Holmes assures Sir Henry that he will share their knowledge about his affairs. They discuss a document cut from a newspaper, and Holmes explains how he deduced which newspaper and article it was from. Sir Henry and Dr. Mortimer express amazement at Holmes' deduction skills.

291-324.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Mortimer discuss the peculiarities of a letter received by Sir Henry, deducing it was written in a hotel based on the state of the pen and ink used. Holmes examines the letter closely, only to find it is a blank half-sheet of paper.
291-324.dialog_summary: Holmes and Mortimer discuss the likelihood that the letter was written in a hotel due to the poor quality of pen and ink. Holmes examines the letter closely but finds nothing further.
text_phrases: holding it only an inch or two from his eyes

291-324.scene_title: Discussion of Sir Henry's Missing Boot
291-324.description: Sir Henry discusses with Holmes and Mortimer about a boot he misplaced in his hotel, which he had put out for cleaning. The conversation reveals Sir Henry's recent arrival and his efforts to fit into his new role.
291-324.dialog_summary: Sir Henry explains the loss of his boot, which he had recently purchased and put out for cleaning. Holmes and Mortimer discuss the triviality and potential implications of the missing boot.
text_phrases: I put them both outside my door last night
I only bought the pair last night in the Strand

291-324.description: Dr. Mortimer recounts the details of the case to Sir Henry, who listens intently and reacts with surprise. The narrative includes the history of the hound and the mysterious circumstances surrounding the family.
291-324.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer presents the case details as previously discussed, involving the legendary hound and the peculiar events affecting the Baskerville family. Sir Henry reacts with surprise and acknowledges the gravity of his inheritance.
text_phrases: drew his papers from his pocket

325-355.description: In the scene, Baskerville expresses his firm decision to return to his ancestral home despite potential dangers, which could be from a family curse or human threats. He invites Holmes and Watson to lunch for further discussion.
325-355.dialog_summary: Baskerville insists on returning to his family home despite warnings of danger and invites Holmes and Watson to discuss more over lunch.
text_phrases: face flushed to a dusky red

325-355.description: Holmes and Watson hastily leave the house to follow Dr. Mortimer and Baskerville, who are ahead of them. They observe a suspicious man in a cab and attempt to pursue him, but he escapes.
325-355.location: Streets of London, from Holmes' residence to Oxford Street
325-355.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss following Baskerville and Mortimer, observe a suspicious man in a cab, and attempt to pursue him but fail.
text_phrases: Your hat and boots, Watson, quick!
hansom cab with a man inside
trapdoor at the top flew up

356-393.scene_title: Conversation and Instructions on Regent Street
356-393.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson saunter down Regent Street, discussing their next moves in the investigation. Holmes instructs a young lad named Cartwright at a district messenger office.
356-393.dialog_summary: Holmes decides not to follow Dr. Mortimer and his companion, discusses the investigation strategy with Watson, and gives detailed instructions to Cartwright about collecting waste-paper from hotels.
object_part_of_object: copy of the Times;district messenger office
text_phrases: turned into one of the district messenger offices

356-393.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson arrive at the Northumberland Hotel where they are greeted by the clerk. Holmes inquires about the hotel register and learns about other guests.
356-393.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson are informed by the hotel clerk that Sir Henry Baskerville is waiting for them. Holmes checks the hotel register and converses with the porter about the guests.
text_phrases: Sir Henry Baskerville is upstairs expecting you

356-393.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson unexpectedly meet an angry Sir Henry Baskerville at the top of the stairs in the Northumberland Hotel.
356-393.dialog_summary: Sir Henry Baskerville expresses his frustration about a missing boot and warns of trouble if it is not found.

394-444.description: A conversation about missing boots between Sir Henry and a German waiter, with Holmes and Dr. Mortimer present.
394-444.dialog_summary: Sir Henry discusses his missing boots, first a brown one and then a black one, with a German waiter who has been unable to find them. Holmes and Dr. Mortimer listen as Sir Henry expresses his frustration and threatens to leave the hotel if the boots are not found.

394-444.description: Holmes and Dr. Mortimer discuss Sir Henry's safety and plans to move to Baskerville Hall, including suspicions around Barrymore and the legacy of Sir Charles.
394-444.dialog_summary: Holmes advises Sir Henry that moving to Baskerville Hall is wise due to being followed in London. They discuss Barrymore's potential presence in London, his inheritance from Sir Charles, and the overall legacy left by Sir Charles. Dr. Mortimer reveals his own inheritance and discusses other beneficiaries.

445-480.description: Sir Henry and Mr. Holmes discuss the inheritance of Sir Charles's estate and the importance of making a will.
445-480.dialog_summary: Sir Henry has not made a will yet and agrees with Holmes on the necessity of the money going with the title to maintain the estate. Holmes advises Sir Henry not to go to Devonshire alone.

445-480.description: Baskerville finds his missing boot under a cabinet in the room after a thorough search.
445-480.dialog_summary: Baskerville finds his missing boot and expresses relief, while Holmes and Mortimer discuss the oddity of its disappearance and reappearance.

445-480.description: Holmes and Watson receive telegrams and discuss their next moves in the investigation.
445-480.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss the implications of the telegrams received, indicating Barrymore's presence at the Hall and the unsuccessful search for the cut sheet of the Times.
text_phrases: unable to trace cut sheet of Times

481-522.description: Sherlock Holmes questions a cabman, John Clayton, about his recent fare who claimed to be a detective and followed two gentlemen. The conversation reveals that the fare was impersonating Holmes himself.
481-522.dialog_summary: Holmes questions Clayton about his fare and discovers that the fare was impersonating him. Clayton describes the events and locations visited throughout the day.
text_phrases: my cab is out of Shipley’s Yard
we pulled up halfway down the street
my gentleman threw up the trap

481-522.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discuss the Case
481-522.description: After the cabman leaves, Holmes and Watson discuss the implications of the case, expressing concern about the challenges ahead as they prepare for their trip to Devonshire.
481-522.dialog_summary: Holmes expresses frustration at being outwitted and discusses the complexity of the case with Watson. They talk about the upcoming trip to Devonshire and the potential dangers.
text_phrases: I will not bias your mind
report facts in the fullest possible manner

523-546.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the list of suspects involved in the case and the precautions they need to take. They are at a train station preparing to depart.
523-546.dialog_summary: Holmes advises against dismissing the Barrymores as suspects, lists other potential suspects, and emphasizes the importance of taking precautions, including keeping a revolver nearby. Dr. Mortimer confirms they haven't been followed, and Holmes warns Sir Henry about the dangers of going out alone.
text_phrases: waiting for us upon the platform
train began to glide down the platform

523-546.description: Holmes, Watson, and Sir Henry travel by train to Devon, discussing their backgrounds and observing the changing landscape.
523-546.dialog_summary: Sir Henry expresses his excitement about returning to Devon, Dr. Mortimer discusses the characteristics of the people from Devon, and they all look forward to seeing the moor.
text_phrases: the brown earth had become ruddy
red cows grazed in well-hedged fields

523-546.description: The group arrives at a small station and observes their surroundings, including the moor and local personnel.
523-546.dialog_summary: The group descends from the train and is greeted by the station-master and porters. They then proceed to travel by wagonette.
text_phrases: train pulled up at a small wayside station
flying swiftly down the broad, white road

547-566.description: The wagonette travels through deep lanes, over a granite bridge, and alongside a noisy stream, rising steadily into the countryside as it approaches Baskerville Hall.
547-566.dialog_summary: Baskerville expresses delight and curiosity about his surroundings, asking many questions.
text_phrases: deep lanes worn by centuries of wheels
noisy stream which gushed swiftly down

547-566.description: The wagonette encounters a stern mounted soldier watching the road, as Dr. Mortimer and the driver discuss the escape of a dangerous convict from Princetown.
547-566.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer and the driver discuss the escaped convict, Selden, and the danger he poses. The driver explains the local farmers' concerns and the reward for information.
text_phrases: rifle poised ready over his forearm

547-566.description: The wagonette arrives at Baskerville Hall, passing through the lodge gates and driving up the dark avenue, as Sir Henry Baskerville reacts to the gloomy atmosphere.
547-566.dialog_summary: Sir Henry expresses his unease and plans to install electric lamps to brighten the place. He reacts to the gloomy surroundings and the history of his family's estate.
text_phrases: lodge-gates, a maze of fantastic tracery in wrought iron
old trees shot their branches in a sombre tunnel
house glimmered like a ghost at the farther end

567-589.description: Sir Henry and Dr. Watson arrive at Baskerville Hall, greeted by a tall man and a woman who assist them with their luggage.
567-589.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer declines dinner at Baskerville Hall as his wife expects him, and he suggests Barrymore will be a better guide.

567-589.description: Sir Henry and Dr. Watson enter the grand hall of Baskerville Hall, observing its antique decor and feeling the warmth of the log-fire.
567-589.dialog_summary: Sir Henry expresses his awe and connection to the hall, reflecting on his family's history.
text_phrases: high, thin window of old stained glass
dim and sombre in the subdued light of the central lamp

567-589.description: Sir Henry and Dr. Watson dine in the gloomy dining room of Baskerville Hall, surrounded by the portraits of ancestors and a subdued atmosphere.
567-589.dialog_summary: Sir Henry and Dr. Watson discuss the somber atmosphere of the hall and plan to retire early.
text_phrases: long chamber with a step separating the dais
little circle of light thrown by a shaded lamp

590-610.scene_title: A Mysterious Night at Baskerville Hall
590-610.description: The narrator is unable to sleep and hears the sob of a woman in the night, which disturbs the silence of the old house.
text_phrases: tossing restlessly from side to side
chiming clock struck out the quarters
rustle of the ivy on the wall

590-610.description: Sir Henry and the narrator discuss their impressions of Baskerville Hall over breakfast, with sunlight streaming through the windows.
590-610.dialog_summary: Sir Henry and the narrator discuss their initial gloomy impressions of the house, attributing it to their tiredness and the chilling drive. They also discuss the mysterious sobbing heard in the night.
text_phrases: sunlight flooded in through the high mullioned windows
watery patches of colour from the coats of arms

590-610.description: Sir Henry questions Barrymore about the mysterious sobbing heard in the night, leading to a tense exchange.
590-610.dialog_summary: Sir Henry questions Barrymore about the sobbing sound. Barrymore denies any knowledge, attributing it to the women in the house, but appears visibly shaken.
text_phrases: pallid features of the butler turned a shade paler
met Mrs. Barrymore in the long corridor

590-610.description: The narrator visits the postmaster to verify whether Barrymore was in London, leading to a conversation with the postmaster and his son.
590-610.dialog_summary: The narrator questions the postmaster and his son about the delivery of a telegram to Barrymore, confirming it was received by Mrs. Barrymore instead.
text_phrases: delivered that telegram to Mr. Barrymore at the Hall

611-640.description: Dr. Watson is surprised by a stranger, Mr. Stapleton, who introduces himself on the moor. Stapleton, a naturalist, carries a butterfly-net and a tin box for specimens, and discusses local legends and Sir Charles's death.
611-640.dialog_summary: Stapleton introduces himself to Watson, discusses the local legend of a fiendish dog, expresses concern for Sir Henry, and invites Watson to visit Merripit House.
text_phrases: voice which called me by name
dark cliff with ferns and brambles

641-678.description: Stapleton discusses the dangerous Grimpen Mire with Dr. Watson, explaining its perilous nature and the deaths it has caused. He also describes the unique flora and fauna of the moor, including rare plants and butterflies.
641-678.dialog_summary: Stapleton explains the dangers of the Grimpen Mire and its surrounding areas, discouraging Dr. Watson from attempting to explore it due to the high risk involved.
text_phrases: head craning out of the bog-hole
brown was rolling and tossing among the green sedges
long, agonised, writhing neck shot upward
dreadful cry echoed over the moor

641-678.description: Dr. Watson and Stapleton hear a strange, mournful sound sweeping over the moor, which locals attribute to the mythical Hound of the Baskervilles. Stapleton dismisses it as natural noises from the bog.
641-678.dialog_summary: Stapleton explains the natural causes of strange sounds on the moor, while Dr. Watson expresses fear and curiosity about the supernatural explanations given by locals.
text_phrases: long, low moan, indescribably sad, swept over the moor
huge swelling plain, mottled with the green patches of rushes
pair of ravens, which croaked loudly from a tor behind us

641-678.description: Stapleton suddenly pursues a small fly or moth across the moor, demonstrating his agility and deep knowledge of the terrain, while Dr. Watson encounters a mysterious woman.
641-678.dialog_summary: Stapleton rushes after a moth, showing his enthusiasm for the natural elements of the moor, while Dr. Watson is left in awe of his agility.
text_phrases: small fly or moth fluttered across our path
Stapleton was rushing with extraordinary energy and speed
creature flew straight for the great mire
green net waving in the air

679-704.scene_title: Encounter with Miss Stapleton on the Moor
679-704.description: Dr. Watson meets Miss Stapleton on a lonely moorland path. She is described as a strikingly beautiful and elegant woman, contrasting sharply with her brother. She urgently warns Watson to leave the moor and return to London for his own safety.
679-704.dialog_summary: Miss Stapleton urgently tells Dr. Watson to return to London for his safety, refusing to explain why. She is interrupted by her brother's arrival and quickly changes the subject.
text_phrases: ladies of any sort must be few upon the moor
sensitive mouth and the beautiful dark, eager eyes
strange apparition upon a lonely moorland path
tapped the ground impatiently with her foot

679-704.scene_title: Introduction and Walk to Merripit House
679-704.description: After the initial encounter, Stapleton joins Watson and his sister, and they briefly converse before walking to Merripit House. The conversation reveals some background about Stapleton's past and his reasons for living on the moor.
679-704.dialog_summary: Stapleton discusses his past running a school and his interests in botany and zoology. Miss Stapleton and Stapleton express their contentment with their life on the moor, despite some reservations.
text_phrases: once the farm of some grazier
put into repair and turned into a modern dwelling

705-726.scene_title: Dr. Watson's Refusal and Return Journey
705-726.description: Dr. Watson resists staying for lunch despite the invitation to view a collection of Lepidoptera, feeling a pressing need to return to his responsibilities. His thoughts are tinged with the melancholy of the moor and recent unsettling events.
705-726.dialog_summary: Dr. Watson expresses his eagerness to return to his charge, resisting the invitation to stay for lunch.
text_phrases: resisted all pressure to stay for lunch
set off at once upon my return journey

705-726.description: Dr. Watson encounters Miss Stapleton unexpectedly on his way back. She apologizes for a previous mistake and expresses her concerns about Sir Henry's safety.
705-726.dialog_summary: Miss Stapleton apologizes for mistaking Dr. Watson for Sir Henry and expresses her concern for Sir Henry's safety, urging him to leave the area due to a perceived danger.
text_phrases: Miss Stapleton sitting upon a rock by the side of the track
held her hand to her side
run all the way in order to cut you off

705-726.scene_title: Dr. Watson's Reflections and Letter to Holmes
705-726.description: Dr. Watson reflects on the grim charm of the moor and its prehistoric inhabitants as he prepares to document his experiences in a letter to Sherlock Holmes.
text_phrases: transcribing my own letters to Mr. Sherlock Holmes
the homes and the work of the prehistoric people

727-733.description: The narrator discusses the situation of an escaped convict on the moor and the relief his disappearance brings to the local householders.
The narrator expresses concern for the Stapletons' safety due to their remote location and the presence of the escaped convict.
727-733.dialog_summary: Discussion about the safety of the Stapletons and the suggestion that Perkins the groom should stay with them for protection, which Stapleton refuses.

727-733.description: Sir Henry and the narrator are taken by Stapleton to the site of the legendary tale of wicked Hugo, sparking a discussion on the supernatural.
727-733.dialog_summary: Sir Henry questions Stapleton about the supernatural, and Stapleton responds cautiously.

727-733.description: Sir Henry meets Miss Stapleton at Merripit House, and they both show a mutual attraction, which concerns Stapleton.
727-733.dialog_summary: Sir Henry and Miss Stapleton meet and show mutual attraction, which displeases Stapleton.
text_phrases: Sir Henry made the acquaintance of Miss Stapleton

734-748.description: Dr. Mortimer discusses his recent excavation and discovery of a prehistoric skull during a lunch at Sir Henry's residence.
734-748.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer shares his excitement about discovering a prehistoric skull.

734-748.description: Dr. Mortimer takes the group to the yew alley to explain the events of the fatal night.
734-748.dialog_summary: Dr. Mortimer explains the sequence of events on the night of the crime.

734-748.description: Introduction to Mr. Frankland, a litigious neighbor who enjoys legal battles and amateur astronomy.
734-748.dialog_summary: Narrative description of Mr. Frankland's character and hobbies, including his passion for litigation and astronomy.

734-748.description: Sir Henry interrogates Barrymore about the receipt of a test telegram to confirm his presence at the house.
734-748.dialog_summary: Sir Henry questions Barrymore about the telegram, and Barrymore explains that his wife handled it.

734-748.description: The narrator observes Barrymore walking stealthily down the corridor with a candle, appearing guilty.

749-763.description: The narrator follows Barrymore and observes him crouching at a window in an unfurnished room, holding a candle against the glass and staring out into the moor.
749-763.dialog_summary: No direct dialogue in this scene.
text_phrases: corridor is broken by the balcony
glimmer of light through an open door
Barrymore was crouching at the window
stared out into the blackness of the moor

749-763.description: The narrator discusses with Sir Henry about Barrymore's nocturnal activities, suspecting a clandestine affair, and they plan to shadow him to discover his intentions.
749-763.dialog_summary: Narrator shares observations with Sir Henry about Barrymore's actions. Sir Henry acknowledges awareness of Barrymore's nocturnal walks and suggests they follow him to learn more. They plan to sit up and observe Barrymore's actions.
text_phrases: went down the corridor and examined the room
western window through which he had stared
nearest outlook on to the moor
had an interview with the baronet in his study

764-777.description: Sir Henry prepares to go out and Watson decides to follow him based on Holmes' instructions to not let Sir Henry go alone on the moor.
764-777.dialog_summary: Watson debates whether to accompany Sir Henry onto the moor, ultimately deciding to follow due to Holmes' strict instructions.
text_phrases: Sir Henry put on his hat

764-777.description: Watson observes Sir Henry and Miss Stapleton from a hill, debating his duty to follow and protect versus respecting their privacy.
764-777.dialog_summary: Sir Henry and Miss Stapleton are in deep conversation, which Watson observes but does not interrupt.

764-777.description: Stapleton interrupts Sir Henry and Miss Stapleton's conversation, leading to a heated exchange and Miss Stapleton leaving with her brother.
764-777.dialog_summary: Stapleton confronts Sir Henry and Miss Stapleton, leading to an argument and Miss Stapleton leaving with Stapleton.
text_phrases: spring apart and turn hurriedly round

764-777.description: Watson meets Sir Henry at the bottom of the hill, explains his actions, and discusses the events that just occurred.
764-777.location: Bottom of the hill near Merripit House
764-777.dialog_summary: Watson explains to Sir Henry why he followed him and witnessed the confrontation, leading to Sir Henry's initial anger and subsequent understanding.
text_phrases: met the baronet at the bottom

778-793.description: Sir Henry recounts his frustrating encounter on the prairie where he attempted to woo a woman but was interrupted and confronted by her protective brother.
778-793.dialog_summary: Sir Henry discusses his failed attempt to woo a woman due to her brother's interference, expressing confusion and seeking Watson's advice on the matter.

778-793.description: Stapleton visits Sir Henry to apologize for his earlier rudeness and explains his deep bond with his sister, leading to a temporary resolution.
778-793.dialog_summary: Stapleton apologizes for his behavior, explaining his fears of losing his sister and agrees to a temporary truce with Sir Henry.
text_phrases: private interview with Sir Henry in his study

794-812.description: Watson and Sir Henry sit up until the early hours of the morning, listening for any sounds but only hearing the chiming clock. They fall asleep in their chairs after a long, quiet vigil.
text_phrases: sat up with Sir Henry in his rooms

794-812.description: Watson and Sir Henry, after hearing a creak in the passage, stealthily follow the sound to catch a glimpse of Barrymore at the window.
794-812.location: Corridor and other wing of the house
text_phrases: creak of a step in the passage
candle framed it in the darkness

794-812.description: Sir Henry confronts Barrymore who is found at the window in the middle of the night, leading to a tense exchange about his actions.
794-812.location: Room with the western lattice window
794-812.dialog_summary: Sir Henry demands the truth from Barrymore about his actions at the window, suspecting him of signaling someone outside. Barrymore appears agitated and defensive but insists on his innocence.
text_phrases: Barrymore sprang up from the window
dark eyes, glaring out of the white mask of his face
holding a candle to the window

794-812.description: Watson takes the candle from Barrymore and uses it to discover a signal response from the moor, confirming their suspicions of a secret communication.
794-812.location: Room with the western lattice window
794-812.dialog_summary: Watson and Sir Henry discover a responding signal from the moor, confirming that Barrymore was signaling someone outside. Barrymore remains defiant and refuses to reveal more information.
text_phrases: took the candle from the trembling hand of the butler
held it as he had done
glowed steadily in the centre of the black square framed by the window

813-842.description: In the Baskerville Hall, Sir Henry confronts the Barrymores about their suspicious activities, leading to Mrs. Barrymore revealing the truth about helping her escaped convict brother, Selden.
813-842.dialog_summary: Sir Henry accuses the Barrymores of betrayal, leading to Mrs. Barrymore's confession about aiding her brother, an escaped convict, by signaling him with lights. Sir Henry and Watson are shocked by the revelation.
text_phrases: Mrs. Barrymore, paler and more horror-struck
bulky figure in a shawl and skirt

813-842.description: After the revelation, Sir Henry and Watson decide to capture Selden, the escaped convict, who is hiding on the moor and being aided by the Barrymores.
813-842.dialog_summary: Sir Henry and Watson resolve to capture Selden after learning he is nearby on the moor. They prepare for the expedition by gathering necessary items like a revolver.
text_phrases: Sir Henry had flung it open
cold night wind beat in upon our faces

843-879.description: Watson and Sir Henry discuss their plan to capture a suspect on the moor at night, hearing a mysterious and haunting cry that unsettles them.
843-879.dialog_summary: Watson and Sir Henry discuss being armed and their plan to surprise a suspect. They hear a mysterious cry, which Sir Henry believes is the cry of a hound. Watson recalls hearing it before and associates it with the Hound of the Baskervilles. They resolve to continue their pursuit despite their fears.
text_phrases: wind through the silence of the night
face glimmered white through the darkness

843-879.description: Watson and Sir Henry spot a signal light on the moor and approach it, discovering a convict who reacts violently upon noticing them.
843-879.dialog_summary: Watson and Sir Henry decide to wait near the light to catch a glimpse of the suspect. Upon seeing the suspect's face, they rush towards him, but he throws a rock and flees.

880-885.description: Two characters are engaged in a futile chase across the moor under moonlight, trying to catch up with a distant figure. They eventually stop, exhausted, and observe a mysterious figure standing on a granite tor.
880-885.dialog_summary: The narrator points out a mysterious figure to the baronet, who dismisses it as a warder. The baronet is not inclined to investigate further due to his shaken nerves from a previous cry.
text_phrases: jagged pinnacle of a granite tor
figure of a man upon the tor

880-885.description: The morning after the chase, the narrator reflects on the eerie and melancholic atmosphere of the moor, surrounded by fog and intermittent rain, contemplating the sinister influences at play.
text_phrases: house is banked in with rolling clouds
thin, silver veins upon the sides of the hills

886-914.description: The protagonist reflects on the possibility that a stranger he saw might be following them, comparing the figure to known individuals and concluding it must be someone new. He resolves to focus his efforts on finding this person.
text_phrases: the stranger whom I saw upon the tor
far taller than that of Stapleton
far thinner than that of Frankland

886-914.description: Barrymore discusses his grievance with Sir Henry regarding the pursuit of his brother-in-law, Selden. Barrymore argues that the pursuit was unfair given his voluntary cooperation.
886-914.dialog_summary: Barrymore expresses his grievance about the pursuit of Selden, arguing it was unfair since he had cooperated voluntarily. Sir Henry and Watson discuss the implications of aiding Selden.
text_phrases: Barrymore asked leave to speak with Sir Henry

886-914.description: After a discussion about Selden, Barrymore hesitates but decides to share a crucial piece of information about Sir Charles's death, revealing he was meeting a woman at the gate.
886-914.dialog_summary: Barrymore reveals that Sir Charles was meeting a woman at the gate on the night of his death, identified only by the initials L.L.
text_phrases: Barrymore hesitated and then came back
stood very pale but very collected
know why he was at the gate at that hour

915-938.description: Barrymore recounts to Sir Henry and Dr. Watson how his wife discovered the remains of a burned letter in Sir Charles's study, which contained a mysterious message signed by 'L.L.'
915-938.dialog_summary: Barrymore explains the discovery of a partially burned letter in the grate of Sir Charles's study, which was found by his wife. The letter asked for it to be burned and mentioned a meeting at the gate at ten o'clock, signed with the initials 'L.L.'
text_phrases: found the ashes of a burned letter
the writing could still be read

915-938.description: Dr. Watson reflects on the harsh conditions of the moor during a rainy walk, where he encounters Dr. Mortimer and discusses the mysterious 'L.L.'
915-938.dialog_summary: Watson and Mortimer discuss the initials 'L.L.' and Mortimer mentions Laura Lyons, who lives in Coombe Tracey.
text_phrases: rain poured down, rustling on the ivy
walked far upon the sodden moor

939-972.description: A conversation unfolds between the narrator and another character about Mrs. Laura Lyons, her unfortunate marriage, and her struggle for a livelihood.
939-972.dialog_summary: The narrator learns about Mrs. Laura Lyons' background, her troubled marriage, and how the local community, including himself, helped her financially.
text_phrases: set her up in a typewriting business

939-972.description: The narrator discusses with Barrymore about a mysterious stranger on the moor and the general unease surrounding the Baskerville estate.
939-972.dialog_summary: Barrymore expresses his concerns about a stranger lurking on the moor and the overall sinister happenings around the Baskerville estate.
text_phrases: noises on the moor at night

973-1006.description: Dr. Watson informs Sir Henry about the discoveries regarding Mrs. Laura Lyons and her connection to Sir Charles Baskerville's death during breakfast.
973-1006.dialog_summary: Watson tells Sir Henry about Mrs. Lyons' letter to Sir Charles and suggests investigating alone for better results.
text_phrases: Dr. Mortimer remained with him at cards
At breakfast, however, I informed him

973-1006.description: Dr. Watson visits Mrs. Lyons in her sitting room at Coombe Tracey to inquire about her correspondence with Sir Charles Baskerville.
973-1006.location: Mrs. Lyons' sitting room in Coombe Tracey
973-1006.dialog_summary: Watson questions Mrs. Lyons about her relationship with Sir Charles, leading to her defensive and eventually cooperative responses.
text_phrases: I told Perkins to put up the horses
a lady, who was sitting before a Remington typewriter

1007-1042.description: The scene involves a tense conversation between the narrator and Mrs. Lyons, where she explains her actions and motivations regarding a letter and her non-appearance at a scheduled meeting with Sir Charles, which coincided with the time of his death.
1007-1042.dialog_summary: Mrs. Lyons explains why she wrote to Sir Charles and asked him to destroy the letter, citing personal troubles and a need for help. She denies meeting Sir Charles at the appointed time and place, attributing her absence to receiving help from another source before the meeting.

1007-1042.scene_title: Reflection and Decision to Investigate the Moor
1007-1042.description: After the interrogation, the narrator reflects on the inconsistencies and doubts about Mrs. Lyons' story, deciding to shift the investigation towards the moor, focusing on finding a mysterious man living in one of the stone huts.
1007-1042.location: Narrator's current location moving to the moor

1043-1067.description: Dr. Watson meets Mr. Frankland outside his garden gate. Frankland invites Watson to celebrate his legal victories and shares his experiences with recent court cases.
1043-1067.location: Outside Mr. Frankland's garden gate, along the highroad
1043-1067.dialog_summary: Mr. Frankland greets Dr. Watson cheerfully, invites him for wine, and shares his triumph in legal matters concerning right of way and property rights. He expresses disdain for the local constabulary and hints at his knowledge about the convict on the moor.
text_phrases: outside the gate of his garden
messenger who takes him his food

1068-1083.description: Frankland and Dr. Watson observe a small figure through a telescope from the leads of the house.
1068-1083.dialog_summary: Frankland urges Dr. Watson to quickly observe a boy through the telescope before he disappears over the hill.
text_phrases: telescope, a formidable instrument mounted upon a tripod

1068-1083.description: Dr. Watson explores the moor and discovers a hut where the mysterious boy might be hiding.
1068-1083.dialog_summary: Dr. Watson reflects on his findings and the implications of the message left in the hut.
text_phrases: circle of the old stone huts
dilapidated opening which served as a door
flat stone served the purpose of a table

1084-1112.description: The sun sets, casting a golden light over Grimpen Mire, Baskerville Hall, and the village of Grimpen. The peaceful scene contrasts with the narrator's inner turmoil as he waits in a hut.
text_phrases: ruddy patches by the distant pools
sat in the dark recess of the hut

1084-1112.description: The narrator hears footsteps approaching the hut and prepares himself by cocking his pistol. Holmes arrives, surprising the narrator with his presence and casual demeanor.
1084-1112.location: Outside the hut in Grimpen Mire
1084-1112.dialog_summary: Holmes greets Watson and suggests he would be more comfortable outside the hut. Watson expresses his surprise and relief at seeing Holmes.
text_phrases: sharp clink of a boot striking upon a stone
shrank back into the darkest corner
cocked the pistol in my pocket
shadow fell across the opening of the hut

1084-1112.description: Holmes and Watson discuss their separate investigations and share findings. Holmes explains his reasons for secrecy and reassures Watson of his importance.
1084-1112.location: Outside the hut in Grimpen Mire
1084-1112.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss how each came to be at the hut, their investigations, and Holmes's reasons for secrecy. Watson expresses his initial suspicions and relief at discovering Holmes.
text_phrases: stub of a cigarette marked Bradley, Oxford Street
Cartwright has brought up some supplies

1113-1144.description: Holmes and Watson discuss in a hut on the moor as dusk settles. Holmes reveals critical information about the case, including the true identity of Miss Stapleton.
1113-1144.dialog_summary: Holmes explains to Watson why he kept him in the dark about his presence on the moor, praises Watson's reports, and reveals that Miss Stapleton is actually Stapleton's wife, not his sister. Holmes also discusses the implications of this deception.
text_phrases: withdrew into the hut for warmth
bundle of papers from his pocket
loaf of bread and a clean collar

1113-1144.description: As night fully sets upon the moor, Watson and Holmes conclude their discussion with Holmes asking Watson about the necessity of secrecy.
1113-1144.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss the implications of the case revelations and Watson questions the need for continued secrecy between them.
text_phrases: night had settled upon the moor
a few faint stars were gleaming in a violet sky

1145-1172.scene_title: Holmes and Watson on the Moor
1145-1172.description: Holmes and Watson hear a terrible scream while discussing their case on the moor at night. They rush towards the source of the sound, encountering various obstacles in the dark, and eventually find the body of Sir Henry Baskerville.
1145-1172.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss the imminent danger to Sir Henry and the progress of their investigation. They hear a scream and rush to find its source, discussing their fears and determination to find the culprit.
text_phrases: My nets are closing upon him
prolonged yell of horror and anguish
dark, athletic outline at the door of the hut
his face peering into the darkness
low, constant murmur of the sea
heavy silence of the windless night
forcing our way through gorse bushes
panting up hills and rushing down slopes
shadows were thick upon the moor
ridge of rocks ended in a sheer cliff
prostrate man face downward upon the ground
the head doubled under him at a horrible angle
ghastly pool which widened slowly from the crushed skull
shadowy moor, half silver and half gloom

1173-1210.description: The scene describes the discovery of a body on the moor, initially mistaken for Sir Henry but later identified as Selden, the convict. The characters express shock and confusion upon realizing the identity of the deceased.
1173-1210.dialog_summary: Characters discuss the identity of the body and the implications of the discovery. They express shock and plan to handle the situation.
text_phrases: body, black and clear against the silvered stones
dripping beard was pointing up to the cold, clear moon
dull red glow of a cigar

1173-1210.description: Stapleton arrives at the scene, surprised to see Watson and Holmes. He reacts to the body, initially thinking it might be Sir Henry, and engages in a conversation about the circumstances of the death.
1173-1210.dialog_summary: Stapleton expresses surprise and concern for Sir Henry, inquires about the circumstances of the death, and discusses his own reasons for being on the moor.
text_phrases: dull red glow of a cigar

1211-1242.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the recent tragic events on the moor with Stapleton, who suggests covering the face of the deceased to protect his sister from fright. Holmes and Watson decide to leave for Baskerville Hall.
1211-1242.dialog_summary: Stapleton suggests taking the deceased to his house but decides against it to avoid frightening his sister. Holmes and Watson discuss the case's complexities and their next moves.
text_phrases: covering the face of the deceased
leaving the naturalist to return alone
figure moving slowly away over the broad moor

1211-1242.description: Holmes and Watson have a deep conversation about the challenges of their current investigation, the nature of their adversary, and the limitations of their evidence as they walk towards Baskerville Hall.
1211-1242.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss the cunning of their foe, the lack of direct evidence linking the hound to the deaths, and their plans to strengthen their case, including involving Mrs. Laura Lyons.
text_phrases: walked, lost in thought, as far as the Baskerville gates

1211-1242.description: Holmes and Watson arrive at Baskerville Hall and share a belated supper with Sir Henry, discussing the case and planning for the upcoming dinner with the Stapletons. Watson also has the difficult task of informing the Barrymores about the recent events.
1211-1242.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson explain part of their experiences to Sir Henry while keeping certain details secret. Watson breaks the news to the Barrymores, leading to a sorrowful reaction from Mrs. Barrymore.
text_phrases: she wept bitterly in her apron

1243-1278.description: Sir Henry discusses his day and a missed opportunity to visit Stapleton due to his promise of not going out alone. Holmes and Sir Henry then discuss the case and the mysterious hound heard on the moor.
1243-1278.dialog_summary: Sir Henry expresses his boredom and restraint due to a promise, while Holmes hints at the dangers he might have faced. They discuss the ongoing case and the supernatural elements they are investigating.
object_part_of_object: roll of paper;Sir William Baskerville portrait
text_phrases: man with the blue coat and the roll of paper
Cavalier with the black velvet and the lace

1279-1322.description: Holmes and Watson discuss a portrait that strikingly resembles Stapleton, leading Holmes to conclude that Stapleton is a Baskerville. Holmes laughs, indicating his confidence in capturing Stapleton soon.
1279-1322.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss how the portrait resembles Stapleton and how it confirms their suspicions about him. Holmes expresses confidence in capturing Stapleton soon.
text_phrases: The face of Stapleton had sprung out of the canvas
a pin, a cork, and a card

1279-1322.description: Holmes and Watson prepare for a busy day, discussing their plans to capture their suspect. Holmes sends reports and communicates with Cartwright, ensuring all preparations are in place.
1279-1322.dialog_summary: Holmes discusses his early morning activities and the plans for the day with Watson. They talk about setting traps and the status of their investigation.
text_phrases: The nets are all in place, and the drag is about to begin

1279-1322.description: Holmes and Watson discuss their immediate travel plans with Sir Henry, explaining the necessity of their departure to London. Sir Henry expresses his disappointment and concern about staying alone.
1279-1322.dialog_summary: Holmes instructs Sir Henry to stay and fulfill his duties while explaining their need to travel to London for urgent business. Sir Henry reluctantly agrees to stay.
text_phrases: You are engaged, as I understand, to dine with our friends the Stapletons tonight
We will drive in to Coombe Tracey

1279-1322.description: Holmes and Watson make their final arrangements before heading to London. They send a boy, Cartwright, with instructions to send a telegram upon his arrival in town.
1279-1322.dialog_summary: Holmes gives Cartwright instructions to send a telegram to Sir Henry upon reaching London. Holmes and Watson then depart for London.
text_phrases: A small boy was waiting upon the platform
You will take this train to town

1323-1360.description: Holmes receives a telegram from Lestrade while discussing plans with Watson.
1323-1360.dialog_summary: Holmes instructs a boy to check for messages at the station office. The boy returns with a telegram from Lestrade confirming his arrival with a warrant.
text_phrases: The boy returned with a telegram

1323-1360.description: Holmes and Watson interview Mrs. Laura Lyons in her office regarding the death of Sir Charles Baskerville.
1323-1360.dialog_summary: Holmes confronts Mrs. Lyons about her involvement and knowledge of Sir Charles' death, revealing that Stapleton's supposed sister is actually his wife. Mrs. Lyons becomes distressed but agrees to cooperate fully.
text_phrases: Mrs. Laura Lyons was in her office
Her hands were grasping the arms of her chair
Here is a photograph of the couple
Read them and see if you can doubt the identity of these people

1361-1387.description: Holmes, Watson, and Lestrade arrive at the station, and Holmes shares that they have a big case ahead. They plan to have dinner before heading to Dartmoor.
1361-1387.dialog_summary: Lestrade greets Holmes and Watson, and Holmes mentions they have a significant case. They discuss plans for dinner and a trip to Dartmoor.

1361-1387.description: Holmes, Watson, and Lestrade, in a wagonette, approach Merripit House under the cover of darkness, discussing their plans in hushed tones.
1361-1387.dialog_summary: Holmes, Watson, and Lestrade talk about the upcoming action, and Lestrade confirms he is armed. Holmes instructs to proceed quietly as they near their destination.

1361-1387.description: Watson observes Sir Henry and Stapleton in the dining room of Merripit House, noting their actions and expressions.
1361-1387.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss the absence of a lady in the house, and Watson reports on the activities of Sir Henry and Stapleton.

1388-1402.description: A dense, white fog drifts slowly towards Holmes and Watson, creating a wall-like barrier. The moon illuminates the fog, giving it a shimmering appearance over the moor.
1388-1402.location: Grimpen Mire, moor near Baskerville Hall
1388-1402.dialog_summary: Holmes notes the fog's movement and expresses concern that it could disrupt their plans and endanger their success and a man's life.

1388-1402.scene_title: The Encroaching Fog and the House
1388-1402.description: The fog continues to encroach upon the house, obscuring the orchard and nearing the lighted windows. Holmes and Watson discuss moving to higher ground to avoid being enveloped by the fog.
1388-1402.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson decide to move to higher ground to avoid the fog. Holmes listens for footsteps, indicating someone is approaching.
text_phrases: golden square of the lighted window
trees were standing out of a swirl of white vapour

1388-1402.description: In a tense and horrifying moment, a gigantic black hound emerges from the fog, glowing with an unnatural fire. Holmes and Watson, along with Sir Henry, confront the beast on the moor.
1388-1402.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson prepare to confront the hound as it emerges. They fire at the hound when it attacks Sir Henry.
text_phrases: fire burst from its open mouth
eyes glowed with a smouldering glare

1403-1432.description: Sir Henry is found insensible and is revived by Holmes and Lestrade with the help of brandy. Holmes confirms the danger has passed as the creature is dead.
1403-1432.dialog_summary: Holmes reassures Sir Henry that the threat is over and the creature is dead. Sir Henry is confused and frightened about the event.
text_phrases: two frightened eyes were looking up at us
he made a feeble effort to move

1403-1432.description: The dead creature, a mix of bloodhound and mastiff, is examined by Holmes and Watson. Holmes deduces the use of phosphorus to create the creature's ghastly appearance.
1403-1432.dialog_summary: Holmes explains the creature was a cunning preparation involving phosphorus, and apologizes to Sir Henry for the fright.
text_phrases: huge jaws seemed to be dripping
my own fingers smouldered and gleamed

1403-1432.description: Holmes, Watson, and Lestrade search Baskerville Hall for the villain, encountering a locked room with a mysterious figure tied to a post.
1403-1432.dialog_summary: Holmes, Watson, and Lestrade discuss the likelihood of finding the villain at the house and decide to search it. They find Mrs. Stapleton tied up and mistreated.
text_phrases: rushed in and hurried from room to room
no light save in the dining-room
glass-topped cases full of butterflies and moths
figure was tied, so swathed and muffled
Mrs. Stapleton sank upon the floor

1433-1447.description: Holmes and Watson speak with Mrs. Stapleton, who reveals the location of her husband's hideout and the hound.
1433-1447.dialog_summary: Mrs. Stapleton reveals that her husband fled to an old tin mine on an island in the heart of the mire, where he kept his hound and made preparations for refuge.
text_phrases: old tin mine on an island

1433-1447.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the impossibility of navigating the Grimpen Mire in the foggy conditions.
1433-1447.dialog_summary: Holmes points out that no one could navigate the Grimpen Mire under the current foggy conditions, while Mrs. Stapleton reacts with merriment about the perilous mire.

1433-1447.description: Holmes retrieves Sir Henry's missing boot from the mire, revealing clues about Stapleton's flight.
1433-1447.dialog_summary: Holmes comments on the significance of finding the boot in the mire, deducing that Stapleton had used it to set the hound on Sir Henry's track and discarded it during his escape.
text_phrases: held an old black boot in the air

1448-1454.scene_title: Holmes and Watson in Baker Street
1448-1454.description: Holmes and Watson are sitting by a fire in their sitting room, discussing past cases and the details of the Baskerville mystery.
1448-1454.dialog_summary: Holmes and Watson discuss the complexities of the Baskerville case and past cases Holmes has solved.

1448-1454.description: Holmes provides a detailed account of Stapleton's background, his real identity, and his sinister plans regarding the Baskerville estate.
1448-1454.dialog_summary: Holmes explains Stapleton's real identity, his past actions, and his plans to acquire the Baskerville estate.

1455-1460.description: Stapleton buys a savage hound and uses artificial means to make it appear diabolical, planning to use it to attack Sir Charles Baskerville.
text_phrases: walked a great distance over the moor

1455-1460.description: Stapleton uses the hound, treated with a glowing paint, to chase Sir Charles down the yew alley, leading to Sir Charles' death from heart disease and terror.
text_phrases: treat it with his infernal paint
fled screaming down the yew alley
hound had kept upon the grassy border

1455-1460.description: Stapleton manipulates Mrs. Laura Lyons by pretending to be a single man and promising marriage, using her to lure Sir Charles for an interview.
1455-1460.dialog_summary: Stapleton deceives Mrs. Lyons into helping him by promising marriage and manipulating her emotions.

1461-1468.description: Stapleton attempts to acquire Sir Henry's old boot to use for controlling a hound, indicating his meticulous planning and criminal intent.
text_phrases: boots or chamber-maid of the hotel

1461-1468.description: Discussion about Stapleton's past crimes and his methodical approach to crime, including his involvement in burglaries and his dangerous nature.
1461-1468.dialog_summary: Discussion on Stapleton's past criminal activities and his strategic methods.
text_phrases: shadowed always by Stapleton in the cab

1461-1468.description: Speculation about who cared for the hound while Stapleton was away, focusing on an old manservant named Anthony.
1461-1468.dialog_summary: Discussion on who might have taken care of the hound during Stapleton's absence.

1461-1468.description: Holmes describes his covert operations to monitor Stapleton, including staying at Coombe Tracey and using disguises.
1461-1468.dialog_summary: Holmes explains his secret movements and strategies to keep an eye on Stapleton without being detected.
text_phrases: stayed for the most part at Coombe Tracey
used the hut upon the moor

1469-1475.description: Holmes recounts the events on the moor where they used Sir Henry as bait to expose Stapleton, leading to a severe shock to Sir Henry but ultimately driving Stapleton to his destruction.
1469-1475.dialog_summary: Holmes explains the strategic use of Sir Henry as bait to catch Stapleton red-handed, resulting in Stapleton's destruction but at a cost to Sir Henry's mental state.
text_phrases: fog which enabled him to burst upon us

1469-1475.description: Mrs. Stapleton confronts her husband about his murderous plans, leading to a furious argument where she decides to betray him.
1469-1475.dialog_summary: Mrs. Stapleton confronts Stapleton about his plans to murder Sir Henry, leading to a heated argument and her decision to betray him.
text_phrases: hound was being kept in the outhouse

1469-1475.description: Holmes discusses the complexities of the case with Watson, including Stapleton's potential plans for claiming his inheritance and their upcoming relaxation plans.
1469-1475.dialog_summary: Holmes explains the difficulties Stapleton faced in claiming his inheritance and invites Watson to a more pleasant evening at the opera.
text_phrases: we may turn our thoughts into more pleasant channels
I have a box for Les Huguenots
be ready in half an hour
